title: Newton 2L rotation - same force and moved rod axis

content.question: A force with magnitude <math alttext="F sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> is applied to the right end of a uniform rod of mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>M</mi></math> and length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> that lies on top of a horizontal surface, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The rod is free to rotate with negligible friction about an axis through its center and perpendicular to the plane of the surface. The rotational inertia of the rod about the axis is <math alttext="One twelfth M L squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mi>L</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, and the rod’s initial angular acceleration is <math alttext="alpha sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>. In a second scenario, the same force is applied to the same rod at the same location, but the axis of rotation is now a distance <math alttext="One third L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> from the left end of the rod, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. This time the rod’s initial angular acceleration is <math alttext="alpha sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="alpha sub 2 over alpha sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mfrac></math> ?
